utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How long has your daughter had trouble breathing?

utterance.speaker: Father
utterance.content: About a week now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The best dads wait two or more.

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: Yeah, no, it's not like it's serious. I-I checked online, and it's… asthma or something.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: "Or something" is the number one killer of teens with no medical degree. When was the last time he took you to see a doctor?

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: Uh, like five months ago. We went a clinic in Trenton. I had strep throat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You remember the antibiotic they gave you? Is it neomycin?

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: Amoxicillin. So about the inhaler for my asthma, I was—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry! Hospital policy specifically prohibits me from giving meds to unrelated homeless people pretending to be father and daughter. Your pants are a size too short, so either you grew a couple of inches or you grabbed the closest size in a thrift store. And only you have dimples, which are adorable, but they're also an x-linked dominant genetic trait. Which actually doesn't prove anything. The fact that you didn't burst into tears tells me that you never thought he was your dad.

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: Let's get out of here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Since you're the brains of the operation, might wanna stick around.

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: What, so I can get busted by Social Services?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, so you can stop bleeding out of your ear. It's usually a sign of a skull fracture. Someone been using your head as a soccer ball?

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Much as I'd like to take your word for it, I have no interest in taking your word for it. No tenderness, no pain. Looks like you might actually be telling the truth about something. Ear canal is fine. You don't have a fever. Pay the man. He's late for a trashcan fire.

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: Would you - would you tell me what's going on? What's wrong with me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I have no idea.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Why'd you ask to meet us 30 miles away from the hospital?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because I can. Also, Chris Christie's blog says the pancakes here are the best. So… what do we got on this 18-year-old with the ear bleed and the breathing problems?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: CT confirms no skull fracture. And looking at her confirms she's not 18.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, she is. Says so in the file.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: We can't treat an underage patient without a guardian. We need to call Social Services.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I cut a deal with the patient. We don't call, she doesn't bolt.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Whatever age, living on the street makes her vulnerable to malnutrition, drug use, H.I.V., all things which could explain her symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No sign of malnutrition. Tox screen is clear. S.T.D. panel was negative. And… is that Foreman?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, my goodness, it is! Hi, Dean Foreman! Are you not gonna introduce us because we're married? Oh, no, wait — that's her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She's a pharmaceutical rep, and this is a working breakfast.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In a restaurant that's nowhere near your home or the hospital.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Chris Christie recommends the pancakes.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Squamous cell middle ear tumor could have caused the ear bleed. Paraneoplastic reaction caused the breathing problems.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Middle ear looks completely normal. But there is thickening in the lining of the wall of the third ventricle. Could be a sign of cerebral infection.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Would explain the lack of fever. Pneumococcus is pretty common among the homeless population. We should find out if she's been vaccinated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure, ask her, and when she refuses to tell you anything, start her on ceftriaxone for pneumococcus.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: And if she says she has been vaccinated?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then don't believe her, and start her on ceftriaxone for pneumococcus.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: How about we don't believe she's gonna bolt and we call Social Services?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: While I'm in the little boys' room, you can pretend that I'm seriously considering that idea.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: The bathroom's that way.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pretty sure there's one in the hospital.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: When I was your age, I ran away. Lived on my own. At the time, it seemed—

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: Oh, let me guess. Life with mom and dad was kind of a drag. So you just ran away, lived with friends, and partied with guys that you knew your parents would hate. And then when you got tired of being a rebel, you just went home. Being homeless isn't a vacation for me. And I'm not acting out. My life at home sucked, so I got the hell out of there.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: There are other options besides living on the streets.

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: Right, like group homes, where you're packed in with as many messed-up delinquent kids as possible; foster parents who only take you in because you're a meal ticket.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I can think of easier ways to make 175 bucks a week.

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: No, you're right — I really should roll the dice and hope for a pair that don't ruin my life the way that my mom— Get your hands off my stuff!

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: The stuff might tell us more about why you're sick. A history textbook. You go to school?

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: I don't plan on being homeless forever.

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: Hello, good sir. My brother, the General here, gots the green-apple quickstep.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: One of us is in the wrong time zone. And if it's me, I need to talk to a stockbroker and anyone from the Kennedy family, in that order.

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: Well, he got the runs, and we do need him up and at 'em for battle tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's hardly authentic, coming to a newfangled clinic, especially with a Yankee doctor.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Sir, are you questioning my resolve?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, and your sanity. I'm multitasking.

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: Uh, General… Don’t light out. We swore that we would see the elephant together.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, far be it from me to come between two nut jobs and their "elephant." I could add some mercury, if you want to make it more authentic.

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: The Confederacy thanks you, Doc.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Got House's phone. Deleted all photos of you and Anita.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I owe you.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: An affair? Never knew you were such a tramp.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Neither did I. Anita, she's fun, smart. Not looking for anything serious. It's-it's… pretty perfect. Except for the gnawing guilt about the husband. The lies she must be telling him.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: But not guilty enough to stop seeing her.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She's smoking hot, and it's not his job to protect her marriage.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Aren't you supposed to be pointing a finger at your own life as a cautionary tale?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: If not for cheating, I might still have a wife, but I wouldn't have Sophie and Sophia. Which means I wouldn't be preparing for their visit this week by child locking all my cabinets, padding table corners, and getting rid of every single magazine.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You could probably just hide the porn in your underwear drawer.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Magazines go away so I won't ignore my children. I know I have to pay attention to them. I want to pay attention to them, but they're just so… boring.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Did you learn anything at Jane Doe's school?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: They did a bunch of vaccinations, including pneumococcus. Take her off the ceftriaxone.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So we're back to square none?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Not exactly. The name she registered under seems to be fake, but the address is a foreclosed house. We'll let you know what we find.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Plenty of food, water.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: And beer.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: She eats well. Goes to school and makes good grades. She's a homeless girl who's captain of the volleyball team.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: How can you be okay with this? Your mom sends you to work with snacks.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: I want and need parents. Jane Doe is flourishing without them.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Maybe. But this mold definitely is.

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: You went to my school. Now that they know, they'll report me. I can't go back there!

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You may have a fungal infection. You need that medicine.

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: Fluconazole, right? I'll get it at a clinic. Ohh! Oh. I can't feel my legs. Hey, wha— is that the infection?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: I don't think so.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So… What causes an ear bleed, breathing problems, and our runaway's inability to run away?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Fungal infection's off the table. What about transverse myelitis?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not with normal posterior column function. I've been waiting to do this for months. Pull! Sights seem to be off on this.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: We didn't call Social Services before because we didn't want the patient to take off. Now she can't. There's no reason for us not to call.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, how about the reason that there's no reason? This is working fine for me. Pull! Well, now, that one clearly took evasive action.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You want to protect her because you think she's fine on her own, outside the system.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does anyone have a position on our patient's medical condition?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Could be endocarditis with septic emboli.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pull! I'd turn around and shoot you, but apparently I'd miss. There's no murmurs, no Osler nodes.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: You've never done this before, have you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I have not. But all the time I had my ankle monitor on, I was furious that I couldn't.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Vasculitis fits.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Start treatment with steroids. She's lucky, she'll be free to flee again.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Not once I call Social Services. I'm not giving up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You wanna bet? One shot, one birdie. You hit, you make the call. You miss, never mention it again.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: No. Why would I agree?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 'Cause your only other option is you call and I fire you.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Pull!

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She responding to corticosteroids?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Looks like it. And Social Services.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I thought for sure there'd be some yelling or profanity, possible bloodletting.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: She's tired of living on the streets after all. I'll bet House re… gret… Could he know I'm good with a gun?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I don't know how, but…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hiring a hooker to pretend to be a social worker?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She took a bet that she knew she'd win. Frankly, I feel violated.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: What happened to the social worker I called?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Apparently, someone identifying themselves as Dr. Pujols called and said the patient ran off.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Come on. "Poo holes."

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I've informed Social Services of the mistake and given Jane Doe's description to the cops. They'll track down the parents.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Thank you. I'll leave you and Dr. "Pujols" alone.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You should have told me you were treating an underage clinic patient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was giving you the gift of deniability.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Now I'm giving you the gift of additional clinic hours.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you're not.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You've got nothing on me. Check your phone.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh… my phone? Oh, right. Yes, I-I did have some pictures on that. But… I also have these. There's the two of you kissing over dinner. Busting a move in a night club. Is that your hand near her nether regions? Thanks again for taking off the ankle bracelet.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm not gonna let you blackmail me, House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, of course not. There's no way someone of your integrity would let me compromise your job in any major way over some tawdry bit of gossip. But what about compromising it in a minor way? Reduced clinic hours. Unlimited Internet porn budget. That makes much more sense than the nuclear option of ruining both our lives. You can keep these. I got copies.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How I miss the sweet smell of stickin' it to the man.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Adams is right. You're protecting this girl.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I was wrong. It's the stench of moralizing. I'm protecting myself from meddling bureaucrats and parents.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You admire this girl. She had a horrible home life, so she went out on her own. She's your road not taken.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I've always dreamed of living in an abandoned house with mold.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House, all I'm accusing you of is having a connection with a patient. This is a good thing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's not a good thing, 'cause it's not a thing.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It is a thing… which she'll prove when her parents show up and you start protecting her from them.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: The sound I make is, moooo! The sound I make is, quack quack quack quack quack. Moo. The sound is quack. Quack quack. Quack quack quack.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I'm an ass. On the plus side, I can now program my DVR from my phone.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: They are kind of boring. All kids, not just yours.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Very helpful.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You need to log more hours. Eventually, you'll pass boredom and get to bonding. Kind of like Stockholm syndrome.

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: I heard the nurses talking. You called Social Services for real.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Because you shouldn't be living on your own.

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: Right, better my mom should use me as a punching bag.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: If your mom abused you, Social Services won't let you go home with her.

utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: Have I mentioned I don't trust the system?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: We don't know if you're better yet. You can't just take off.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Uh, can we help you?

utterance.speaker: Brown
utterance.content: I'm Adele Brown from Social Services, and this is—

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: I'm Ellen Rogers. Callie's mother.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: You haven't been that for two years.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: I promise, things are different.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: Mom… two sentences in, and you're already making promises.

utterance.speaker: Brown
utterance.content: Okay, maybe we need to take a minute here and give Callie some space.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: No, I don't need a minute. I need her out of my life.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: Is she okay?

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: I will be once you just…

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: Oh, my God!

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We need help in here!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Go!

utterance.speaker: Announcer
utterance.content: And they're off!

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You bet 100 bucks on a turtle race?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I paid Mr. Chips 5 bucks to take a dive.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: The bleeding stopped on its own. She got worse after being on steroids, so autoimmune is out.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Diagnosis depends on whether the blood was coming from the sinuses, lungs, or her guts. Mr. Chips looks like he wants it. 100 bucks says he'll make soup out of Franklin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're on.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: How'd the mom seem to you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you're asking him if she looks like someone who beat her kid, you're a moron.

utterance.speaker: Parks
utterance.content: Move your ass, Mr. Chips!

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You should have seen her face when mom walked in. Callie hates her. I don't think she's lying.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Because people never lie about people they hate. Big sinus bleed could be sinusitis and a bleeding disorder.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She didn't complain about a headache.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: The bleeding is in her gut. Could be Zollinger-Ellison. Acid reflux causes asthma, and the acid erodes the stomach, causing the bleeding.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Franklin rules. Mr. Chips drools. Mr. Chips's owner only feeds him on apples and bananas. Nowhere near enough vitamin A. Pay up. And do an upper endoscopy to confirm for Zollinger-Ellison, after Mommie Dearest has given her permission.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Ellen shouldn't have consent if she beat her daughter.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Doesn't matter if she beat her daughter. Only matters if Social Services says she beat her daughter. Good thing you made it all official.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: Will the endoscopy be painful?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Is that an issue? It's a medical procedure. There will be some discomfort.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: I never meant to hurt my daughter.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: And yet you hit her.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: She told you that?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: And now you're gonna tell me you didn't.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: I'm a drug addict. And I've been a lousy mom. Especially since my husband died. I mean, he was closer to Callie than I was, and I missed him… so much. And it was too hard. And taking Oxy just… made things easier. Right up until it made me lose my daughter. I hurt Callie a lot. But one of the only things that I can feel okay about is that I never hit her.

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: Didn't peg you as the midday fun kind of guy. So glad I was wrong.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ohh. Unfortunately, that's not why we're here. Remember that guy from the restaurant yesterday?

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: Mm-hmm.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He's got pictures of us. He's threatening to show your husband.

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: I thought you said that guy was one of your best doctors.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not one of my best people. We've gotta stop seeing each other.

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: Not necessarily. I told my husband about you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What? Why?

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: He was saying that things had been better lately between him and I, that I was happier. I said that I was. And that you were the reason.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And… he was okay with that?

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: Not initially. It was a pretty tough conversation. Neither of us is ready

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You didn't need to shoot yourself. I could have given you a Section 8.

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: We've hit the drills pretty hard, and by the fourth round, my hand went numb. The-the gun slipped and— I only had blanks in it, but…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's funny how nearly shooting your toe off cured that speech impediment.

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: Ah. Yeah. Sorry about that. Sheldon's a… progressive.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eh — compared to who? Rupert Murdoch?

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: Progressives are reenactors who strive for complete authenticity. They never drop character while in uniform.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Whereas you just dabble in crazy.

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: Sheldon and I had a big falling out years ago. We only really started talking again because of the reenactments. They, uh… gave me my brother back.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's a very moving story. Be a lot more affecting if you hadn't bonded over something so completely idiotic.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Your mom didn't hit you, did she?

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Then why'd you lie about it?

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: Because I wanted to get out of here. People understand getting hit more than what my mom does.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Tell me. Maybe I'll understand.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: Well, I was the mom. She couldn't keep a job. Spend all her money on pills. I had to get a job. Double shifts, just to keep the power on. Keep food in the house. I couldn't tell you how many times she nearly O.D.ed and I had to clean her up and put her in bed. So… I decided, if I was gonna be the grown-up, I'd rather do it on my own terms.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Your mom knows she messed up. She's determined not to do it again.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: Yeah. And she'll feel that way, right up until things get too tough and she has to start using again.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Do you think people can change?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No. But I don't think that's gonna change your opinion, because… people don't change.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Stop. Is that an ulcer?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, it is. But we haven't reached the stomach yet. I'm still high in the esophagus. Means it's not Zollinger-Ellison.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Ulcer's bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We need to lavage before she drowns in her own blood.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Cauterized the ulcer, stopped the bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Compromised immune system from living on the street could have made her susceptible to HPV.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: HPV was covered on the STD panel. She's negative. What if she didn't get this from being homeless? What if she got it from her mom?

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: I'm assuming you're thinking something genetic, because—

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: I'm thinking addiction. Alcohol-induced esophagitis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Explains esophageal ulcers and her other symptoms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If only it would explain why we've never seen her drunk, drinking, or detoxing.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Her blood pressure's been elevated. Could be the DTs.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's been mildly elevated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mildly elevated BP could put her at risk of a Berry aneurysm. Weak blood vessel in the brain gets pounded on by elevated BP, causes it to expand and contract. Causes the symptoms to come and go.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: CT didn't show any signs of an aneurysm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did I mention they come and go? Much as your presence may cause objects to become engorged with blood, sometimes aneurysms just aren't in the mood.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Alcoholism and Berry aneurysm are both valid theories. I think we should discuss this with the patient and her mom.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why? We discussed it right here. Go tell 'em she needs a cerebral angiogram to locate the aneurysm, then surgery to repair.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: Brain surgery? When?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We booked the O.R. for an hour from now.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: And Dr. House is sure that's what she has?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He's confident in the diagnosis. It's consistent with all of her symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: But you don't buy it.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: No. I think your symptoms are the result of alcohol abuse.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: But I'm not — I'm not an alcoholic.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You came to the hospital with beer in your pocket. We found more alcohol at your house.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: Yeah, I use booze as payment. I have an occasional beer with my friends. That doesn't mean I have a problem. I want the surgery.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Actually, it's your mom's decision.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: I'm not an addict.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: That's what I always said to you, Callie, but I had a problem—

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: I'm nothing like you! Tell them to do the surgery.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: I need a few minutes to think.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: The patient asked me what I thought.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I pay you to think inside this room. Outside this room, I pay you to parrot.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: It's her choice. She has the right to know!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's a medical choice that you turned into an extension of your baggage and hers. You told the mom something you want to believe because you don't want to believe that this girl might be doing fine parent-free. Which also happens to be what the mom wants to believe.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You think she wants to feel responsible for her daughter's illness?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That woman sees everything to do with her daughter through… guilt-colored glasses. It's all her fault.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: House… don't… bully her. She's overwhelmed enough.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, it's nothing compared to how she's gonna feel when her daughter dies from the aneurysm she decided not to treat.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: You must be Dr. House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I save my appearances for when parents are on the brink of doing something incredibly stupid. Your daughter has a Berry aneurysm. She needs surgery. What she does not need is you making this or any other decision.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: Well, I can't just leave this up to her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then leave it up to me, and just leave.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: Ohh. I'm not gonna abandon my daughter.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She hates you. It's actually not such a big deal. There's plenty of kids who hate their parents. What makes it a big deal is that she should hate you. Playing the biology card doesn't change anything except where she lives. Your daughter is better off without you. So… let her be better off without you. I'm gonna do the surgery. I'll take the fallout from Social Services.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: Dr. House! My daughter's care is my choice. And so is this. Treat her for alcoholism.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Peek-a-boo!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why would Anita tell her husband about our affair?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Probably just got sick of lying. Look at it this way. Now the sex is both commitment- and guilt-free. And men love commitment-free sex. Yes, they do. Oh, yes, they do! They're gonna find out eventually. Peek-a-boo! Peek-a-boo!

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: How do you keep doing the same thing over and over with the same level of enthusiasm?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: First off, be a decent, empathetic person. This is what you said you wanted, but you're actually more upset now that her husband knows.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: 'Cause I'm hurting him.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You always were.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, but he didn't know that. Which means he wasn't really hurt. Yeah, I know it's a rationalization, but it went a long way to making me feel… a little less guilty about seeing her.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Looks like you're gonna need a bigger rationalization. Ahh… peek-a-boo! Peek-a-boo!

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Social Services report came in on your mom.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: Ah, let me guess. She passed with flying colors. She always does.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: I think she might make it this time. House left a bottle of Vicodin to see if she'd steal it. She gave it back. You could at least let her sleep in the room.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: She could have listened to me about my drinking. I mean, even if you are right about it, why take your word over mine? I'm her daughter.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Because it… She's your mom. And, for the first time, she's acting like it.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: It's a little late for that. Good night.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Morning!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I heard you went head-to-head with the mom.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not for your reasons.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're protecting the girl.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm protecting my diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And you tested her — see if you could get her back on drugs and out of her daughter's life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That was to show Adams that Mommie Dearest hadn't changed. I'm taking a principled stand against idealism.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Your patient's stable? Well, maybe Adams was right. The illness is alcohol-related.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I hope so, considering it's what we're treating her for.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You-you hope you're wrong for the sake of the patient?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I hope that I'm right but the aneurism bursts without killing her. Call me a softie. Or the mom agrees to an autopsy so I can prove it.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Your patients love you because you're empathetic.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I also have kind eyes. Why are you here?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: But you don't love all your patients?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Of course not.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I'll-I'll bet some of them bore you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Dull people get cancer too. Why are you here?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: But you… fake an interest in them because you needed to, right? And if you do it long enough, it becomes real?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, no, because the interest isn't fake.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Really? Because you realize they're not dull. It was just your misinterpretation of them.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I just haven't found a way to make them interesting yet. It's all about common ground. You find one thing you both like or hate. John Woo movies, romance novels, kale… Sometimes, the best way to connect with someone is stop thinking about them and focus on yourself. Wh-uhh. What is this about?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Not everything has an agenda. See ya.

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: I told him because it was the right thing to do.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: This doesn't change anything between us.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It… sort of does for me.

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: Y-you want to stop seeing each other?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No. I was thinking… maybe you could tell your husband that we did.

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: And then go back to sneaking around behind his back?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: Why would you want to do that?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don't know. I… This just feels… wrong.

utterance.speaker: Anita
utterance.content: I th-I think I'm gonna go.

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: Ohh, God. We thought it was the salt pork.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But all the menfolk been eatin' it, and we the only ones that's sick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which one of you is the cheap bastard? Your uniforms. They're not wool. They're polyester. Cheap polyester. Which gets processed with a heavy metal called antimony. You wear badly processed polyester all day and night for days and nights, you get antimony poisoning, which caused your diarrhea and your numbness in your hands. And your collective vomiting.

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: Polyester uniforms?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I was being authentic.

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: With polyester uniforms?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The Confederacy gave men $21 every six months—

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: You poisoned us both.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: At least I have principles.

utterance.speaker: George
utterance.content: Because they don't cost anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Brother against brother. Now, that is authentic.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: I know you don't want me here, but, um… They had banana muffins downstairs. Reminded me of our St. Pete's trip. Remember? We used to walk and get some every morning at that bakery.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: I guess. Were you high on that trip?

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: Not when we were together. I used to wait until you went to bed.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: You can stay. If you want.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Callie
utterance.content: Mm. It's not bad.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: What's happening? Is this from the alcohol treatment?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: I was wrong. The Berry aneurysm must have just burst.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Temporal lobes are clear. Parietal, clear.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Get me a micro-vascular clip tray as well as the occlusion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Check the ventricles.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Ventricles are clear too.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Aneurysm must have leaked instead of burst. Inject the dye.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Posterior cerebral clear. Vertebral clear. Circle of Willis also clear. She doesn't have a Berry aneurysm.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Her BP's dropping. Start her on pressors. We gotta get her BP up before her organs start shutting down.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Adams… with me.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Pressors will only give us a couple hours, Max.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What causes breathing issues, bleeding issues, paralysis, loss of consciousness? What are we missing?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: That's everything bad that's happened. What about the good stuff?

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: You mean like we should be more optimistic?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: She got a little better when we put her on steroids, which can attack tumor cells. Maybe she has cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No hypercalcemia, no elevated blood proteins.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: She and her mom mentioned a trip they took to Florida a couple years ago —what about dengue fever? Cholera?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great ideas, if dengue fever or cholera laid in wait for two years before suddenly…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did your biological daughter go swimming in Florida? In a lake or a pond or an Everglade?

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: Uh…yeah. There's a canal near my mother's house. Do you know what's wrong with her?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Family vacations kill. Come with me. Don't want to explain this twice.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You're letting in the flies. And she needs an LVAD.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, she doesn't. Your daughter has ascariasis. It's a disease caused by a parasitic worm found in feces. Animals use the canal as a potty, the eggs from the feces ended up in Callie's intestines when she went swimming… where they hung out, quietly and asymptomatically, biding their time till, somewhere along the way, they got knocked loose. Maybe a dive in volleyball practice or maybe she slipped on her way into a soup kitchen. But once they hatched, the worms got to work on her lungs, her ear, the nerves in her legs. The worms got agitated by the steroids we gave her, which started them on their journey to the esophagus and, ultimately, to the heart. A few pills of Mebendazole… She'll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: She's feeling much better. Walking on her own.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Getting along with her mother?

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: As long as I keep bringing her muffins.

utterance.speaker: Ellen
utterance.content: Did someone come take her for a test?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Callie agrees with you… that people don't change. She said when her mom slips again, she didn't want to be there. She'd rather remember her like she is now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Smart girl.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You got the ending you wanted.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 'Cause I was only looking to solve the case, not their lives. Now, I don't care if the people who work for me are screwed up. In fact, I even encourage it. But absolution? You do that on your own time. Or not at all. 'Cause… clearly, you suck at it.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: This is Aaron Rodgers. Wow, 127 quarterback rating. You know what sound he makes? Grrrrr! Okay. Oy! Um… This… is Terrell Owens. People call him "T.O." Do you know what sound he makes? Wah! Wah! Wah! Wah! Wah!

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: This is Mark Sanchez. Do you know what sound people make about him? Pffftt!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Working late? Husband have her tonight?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And every night. She broke it off. It's for the best. I'm not really an affair guy after all.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure you are, buddy. You just lost interest once it stopped being an affair. That's why you're relieved. But don't worry — it's not gonna end here. You'll just have to get your adrenaline fix somewhere else. When that doesn't do it anymore, then you'll just… escalate things somehow. At least, that's what I've been told.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm not like you, House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: True. No limp.
